title: HTTPS Usage
content: Legitimate websites usually use HTTPS. A missing HTTPS (HTTP only) is a red flag for phishing. Phishing sites often skip HTTPS to avoid certificate registration.

title: URL Length
content: URLs longer than 100 characters are often phishing attempts. Attackers use long URLs to obscure the real domain or include deceptive parameters.

title: Number of Subdomains
content: Phishing URLs frequently use many subdomains to mimic legit services (e.g., login.paypal.com.fake-domain.com). More than 3 subdomains is suspicious.

title: Use of IP Address
content: Phishing URLs sometimes use raw IP addresses instead of domain names to hide their origin. URLs like http://192.168.1.1/login are a common red flag.

title: Favicon Check
content: Legitimate sites usually provide a favicon. If a page is missing a favicon, it might be hastily built or cloned by an attacker.

title: URL Contains @ Symbol
content: URLs containing '@' can trick browsers by treating the string after '@' as the real destination. This is a classic phishing trick.

title: Redirection in URL
content: Multiple redirections in a URL or presence of // after the domain (like http://site.com//evil.com) may be used to confuse users. This is suspicious.

title: Mismatch in Domain and Title
content: If the page title doesn’t match the domain (e.g., domain is random.com but title says 'Facebook Login'), it’s likely a phishing page.

title: URL Has Suspicious Keywords
content: Keywords like 'secure', 'login', 'update', 'free', or 'verify' in the path or domain are common in phishing URLs.

title: No External Links
content: Legit websites usually contain multiple external references (like social media, CDNs, ads). A complete lack of external links is suspicious.

title: Responsive Design
content: Most modern websites are responsive. A non-responsive page could be a quickly assembled phishing site not intended for mobile.

title: Short URL Services
content: Use of shortened URLs (bit.ly, tinyurl, etc.) is often seen in phishing campaigns to mask the true destination.

title: Presence of Forms
content: A form asking for sensitive info (passwords, card details) without HTTPS or validation is a major phishing signal.

title: Low Domain Age
content: Domains registered recently (within 6 months) are more likely to be phishing. Attackers frequently register throwaway domains.

title: Known Phishing Patterns
content: Common phishing patterns include URLs mimicking login pages, spoofing banking sites, and using urgency (e.g., 'Act Now!') in the text.
